text: What's up, everyone?

If you're looking to create
your first big data application,
stick around, this episode is for you.

Today's episode comes from Kesha
based in Atlanta, Georgia.

Kesha is a software engineer,
tech instructor, active speaker,
and loves all things machine learning.

She's passionate about mentoring
and empowering women, youth,

and underrepresented groups
of people in tech.

Now, she wants to use her skills
to shed light on income inequality.
Let's hear what Kesha has to say.

I've been in the IT industry
for 25 years,

and I'm a strong advocate for diversity
and inclusion, and equity in tech.

I'd like to build an app
called Salary Overflow,

think, Stack Overflow,
but for salaries,

that focuses on tech equity
and uses artificial intelligence

to democratize tech salaries
and drive equal pay in the industry.

Imagine if you had a job offer,
if you could pull up information

to see what other software engineers
like you earn at this company,

or what people who aren't like you
earn at this company.

That would help
with your salary negotiations.

Or what if you could see
the salary projections
or predictions for people like you

over the course of a career
in a particular role.

Kesha wants to build an application
that allows anyone

to understand their salary potential
and shed light on income inequality.
I love what Kesha is doing here,

which is one of the reasons
why I had to have her story on the show.

Along the way, I'll also give you tips
to build the foundation
for your first big data application.

The first question to ask
when starting a big data application is,
"Do I have a data set?"
Right now, Kesha doesn't,

so she'll need to build applications
to collect data,

and then build the infrastructure
to ingest and analyze it.
To gather as much data as possible,

I recommend that Kesha create surveys
on her website and on Facebook.

The mechanisms for her to collect data
might change over time,

but the process to prepare
and analyze them will stay the same.
To create a survey on her site,

Kesha can use APIs
created with Amazon API Gateway
and AWS Lambda.

API Gateway is a great service
that simplifies the process of creating,
managing, and securing your APIs.

Lambda allows you to run code
without managing servers.

The responses to the survey
will write to Amazon DynamoDB.
DynamoDB is a NoSQL database

that delivers single-digit
millisecond performance at any scale.

The next step is to prepare
this data for analysis.

AWS Glue is a fully managed service
to extract, transform,
and load data.

Use AWS Glue to crawl your survey
answer DynamoDB tables.

The AWS Glue extract, transform,
and load library

natively supports partitions
when you work with dynamic frames.

Partitioning is an important technique
for organizing your data sets
so they can be queried efficiently.

Dynamic frames represent
a distributed collection of data

without requiring you
to specify a schema.

A Crawler in Glue
will run through your data
and do three things.

One, classify your data
to determine the format, schema,
and any associated properties.

Two, group data into tables
or partitions.

And three, write metadata
to the data catalog.

This data catalog is your single pane
of everything related to extracting,
transforming, and loading your data.

With Glue, you can write scripts
in Python or Scala

or just like Glue figure out
how to crawl your data.

If you don't set the Glue Crawler
right the first time, don't worry,

even I got stuck with Glue
the first few times I tried.

The data that Glue extracts
will go into Amazon S3 for analysis.
In other episodes,

I discussed how S3 can store
front end code and images,
plus even host a static website.

S3 can also store data which is useful
when you don't know what structure

or you're collecting it
from multiple sources.

S3's unlimited storage capacity
makes it great
for big data applications.

This architecture pattern for storing
and analyzing data

from multiple sources,
is referred to as a data lake.
Now that you know what data lake means,
you can feel more confident

dropping this buzzword
into conversations with your boss.

Kesha also wants to include
her Facebook survey data
in her analysis.
To do this,

extract the Facebook survey data
into a Microsoft Excel file
and drop it into S3.

Then, run a Glue job to extract,
transform,
and load this data for analysis.

Now you can query
and even join the two datasets
with Amazon Athena.
Athena combines the strength of Presto,

with the serverless
and self-managed capabilities of AWS,

a combination that rivals peanut butter
and chocolate.

to store information and schemas
about the databases and tables

that you create for your data
stored in Amazon S3.

The best place to secure access
to your data lake
is with AWS Lake Formation.

Lake Formation provide a single view
for managing all of the services
of your analytics workflow,

including S3 buckets, Glue jobs,
and Athena tables.

For those who enjoy analyzing big data
with Python,
I suggest using Amazon SageMaker.

Amazon SageMaker
is a machine learning service

that allows data scientists
and developers

to quickly and easily train, build,
and deploy machine learning models.

You could take advantage of SageMaker's
fully managed infrastructure

to quickly run
statistical Python packages
like NumPy and Pandas.

You'll also be set up to use SageMaker
for machine learning in the future.
After analyzing your data,

you definitely want
to share visualizations of it.

To include jaw-dropping charts
in your app,
I recommend using Amazon QuickSight.

QuickSight is a fast cloud-powered
business intelligence service
that makes it easy to deliver insights.

QuickSight seamlessly connects
to your data in S3 or Athena.

Be sure to choose Athena
as your data source
if you created new tables with it.

Use the QuickSight JavaScript SDK
to embed charts in your app.

For example, you can show a chart
of the top five cities in the US

with the highest average salaries
for senior software engineers
broken down by gender.

Kesha also wants Salary Overflow
to answer specific user questions, like:

what do black women software engineers
earn in Atlanta?

I have a job offer,
is this offer comparable

These specific questions
can be answered by utilizing an API,

just like before
when Kesha created the survey
with API Gateway and Lambda.

The Lambda functions for this API
will process requests by querying Athena

and sending the response
back to the front end.

The results from the Athena query
are stored in Amazon S3,

which can be used to respond
to repeat requests
instead of re-running the query.
Now, it's time for a recap!

Collect data using Lambda and DynamoDB
to survey users on your site.

Next, move the response data into Glue
for data transformations.

The result of that transformation
and all other data
will land in your data lake on S3.
Run queries on that data with Athena.

Use QuickSight to embed charts
or dashboards on your app.

To integrate that data
into your application,
make a request to API Gateway,

which will invoke Lambda
to query Athena.

Secure and manage workflows
in your data lake with Lake Formation.

That's how you build
a big data application.

It doesn't matter when you start
